awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research:   Immiscible Phase Interface-Driven Processing of Ultrafine-Laminated Structures for Lightweight and Strong Magnesium-Based Sheets
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnesium (Mg) is the lightest non-hazardous structural metal, and its alloys have tremendous potential for achieving energy efficiency in the aerospace and automotive industries. Magnesium alloys often lack strength and formability, however, and traditional pathways for overcoming these drawbacks are insufficient and costly. Two-phase laminated materials, consisting of an Mg alloy phase and another distinctly dissimilar metal phase, have the potential to overcome these challenges. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental scientific research needed to achieve the processing breakthrough of making the first two-phase, finely laminated structures of Mg alloys, by first understanding the mechanisms by which these materials deform under applied load. One key element that fuels this project is the use of a new Mg alloy, called Mg500, which does not contain rare earth elements, and has very low aluminum content, making it an excellent candidate for many applications. The extraordinarily high density of Mg500/Niobium interfaces will permit multiple functions not possible in Mg-based materials to date. Understanding the deformation of these materials systems will make a critical contribution to the next generation of lightweight structural materials for automotive and aerospace applications. In addition, this research program will provide excellent educational opportunities for students, and training for the next generation of scientists and engineers in both academic and industrial settings. The new knowledge derived from this work will be disseminated broadly though software, tutorials and cloud-based Apps for data distribution.

The scientific goals of this research program are to advance understanding on how hexagonal close-packed (HCP)/body-centered cubic (BCC) interfaces can control slip and twinning in novel ultra-fine laminated metallic composites and, as a result, radically enhance strength and formability. It is a cooperative program that joins the University of California at Santa Barbara, the University of New Hampshire, and the industrial partner, nanoMAG, LLC. The research activities are driven by hypotheses that HCP/BCC interfaces can thwart macroscopic instabilities and promote uniform deformation and formability. Together this university-industry team will carry out an integrated experimental and modeling strategy to understand how Mg500/Nb (HCP/BCC) interfaces can control plasticity processes, enabling homogeneous deformation of high-strength (>1 GPa) Mg-based sheets to moderate strains (> 5%). This understanding will be integrated into a predictive multi-scale, interface-sensitive model for linking microstructural evolution during processing with mechanical performance.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project studied a new biocompatible Mg alloy by our GOALI partner, Dr. Decker, called BioMg250. To be non-hazardous, biocompatible Mg alloys are free of aluminum and rare-earth elements and have low concentrations of alloying elements, but as a result, they are typically weaker than conventional Mg alloys. Our studies showed that BioMg250 achieved an optimal tensile yield and ultimate strength of 267 MPa and 307 MPa, respectively, and ductility of 21% and compression strength and strain to failure of 441 MPa and 8.5%, respectively. These properties are outstanding compared to many other Mg alloys, particularly those that are also biocompatible material candidates. We explain that this material has an unusually highly heterogeneous microstructure, containing submicron, nanoscale and atomic-size hard clusters. We also developed a second variant of this material to extend its ductility to 32% to make it suitable for accumulative roll bonding (ARB).

As part of this project, students had the opportunity to engage in learning experiences outside the classroom. Both undergraduate and graduate students traveled to Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) or NanoMag, LLC to perform accumulative roll bonding (ARB) on Mg and Mg/Nb laminates and study the behavior of novel Mg alloys. During these external internships, students had the opportunity to interact directly with scientists and metallurgists in their laboratories over long periods of time, extending many months. To take advantage of our nation?s user facilities as part of their research, students had the opportunity to help prepare or directly lead user proposals that successfully achieved beam time or research funds at the Advanced Proton Source, LANL Los Alamos Neutron Science Center, and LANL Institute of Materials Science. As a related outcome, interest in the topic of this project and student research results motivated development of two lecture modules--one focused on processing/microstructure/property relationships and another on deformation twinning--that were integrated in academic courses and summer schools.

Using ARB, we manufactured Mg/Nb laminates with a fine layer thickness of 150 mm, the finest achieved to date in the community. The Mg phase is the ductile variant of the novel BioMg250 alloy and the Nb phase was a high-purity form. The ARB processing route required high-temperature intermediate annealing (400 C for one hour) between passes, small rolling reductions per pass, and Mg-cladding, all essential steps for success. The insight gained from our experience provides promising directions for achieving even finer layer thicknesses in other material systems using this same technique.

Using advanced modeling frameworks and microscopy, we studied the effect of interfaces and the Mg/Nb layering on a deformation mechanism called deformation twinning.  This mechanism is common and prevalent in Mg alloys, especially when they are lightly alloyed, such as BioMg250. Deformation twins are natural shear localizations that can lead to deformation instabilities, making manufacturing ultra-fine Mg/Nb laminates difficult. Understanding the microstructural and interface properties that control twinning is crucial for the design of multilayered Mg-based laminates. We found that while deformation twinning in the Mg phase occurs after the first ARB pass, the volume fraction of twins does not increase with more ARB passes. Advantageously, with the processing route we used, the reduction in layer thickness suppresses twinning and homogeneous deformation was observed. With a 3D computational materials technique, we calculated the local stresses that develop around newly formed twins in Mg/Nb multilayers of varying Mg-layer thicknesses. Compared to pure Mg, twinning is more constrained in the Mg layers, since the adjoining Nb layers provide a stiffer constraint on the abutting Mg twin than another Mg crystal. The calculations reveal a critical size below which twin growth in the Mg layer would be hindered. The computational mechanics model for two-phase laminates and the understanding gained on the effects of layering on deformation twinning can be used to help design other Mg-containing laminate material systems. 



Last Modified: 09/10/2021
Modified by: Irene J Beyerlein
